entities.name: Olympic Games
entities.description: The Olympic Games are one of the most prestigious and celebrated sporting events in the world, with a rich history dating back to ancient Greece. They have evolved from their origins as a religious festival dedicated to Zeus into a global event that promotes unity, sportsmanship, and excellence.

entities.name: ancient Greece
entities.description: Ancient Greece was a civilization that developed from the period of the Greek Dark Ages (c. 1200–800 BC) to the end of antiquity (c. AD 600). It is known for its significant contributions to philosophy, literature, art, and science.

entities.name: Zeus
entities.description: Zeus is the king of the gods in Greek mythology and was honored during the ancient Olympic Games.

entities.name: ancient beginnings
entities.description: The ancient beginnings of the Olympic Games refer to the early stages and origins of this prestigious sporting event, which can be traced back to ancient Greece.

entities.name: 776 BC
entities.description: The year in which the ancient Olympic Games were first held in Olympia, Greece.

entities.name: Greece
entities.description: Greece, officially the Hellenic Republic, is a country located in southeastern Europe. It has a rich history and culture, including being the birthplace of the Olympic Games.

entities.name: city-states
entities.description: City-states were independent political entities in ancient Greece, each with its own government and laws. They often competed against each other in various aspects, including sports.

attributes.Characteristics: Independent political entities with their own governments and laws

entities.name: Theodosius
entities.description: Theodosius was the Roman Emperor who abolished the ancient Olympic Games in 393 AD.

entities.name: Roman Empire
entities.description: The Roman Empire was one of the most significant and influential empires in ancient history, known for its vast territories, advanced legal system, and cultural achievements.

attributes.Time Period: 27 BC - 476 AD (Western Roman Empire), 330 AD - 1453 AD (Eastern Roman Empire)
attributes.Religion: Initially polytheistic, later adopted Christianity as the state religion

entities.name: pagan festival
entities.description: A pagan festival is a religious or cultural celebration that predates Christianity and often involves rituals, ceremonies, and games dedicated to deities.

attributes.Purpose: Celebration of deities and cultural values

entities.name: Christianity
entities.description: Christianity is one of the world"s major religions, centered on the life and teachings of Jesus Christ.

entities.name: 19th century
entities.description: The 19th century spans from the year 1801 to 1900. It was a period marked by significant industrial, political, and cultural changes.

entities.name: Pierre de Coubertin
entities.description: Pierre de Coubertin was a French educator and historian who is credited with reviving the Olympic Games in the late 19th century.

entities.name: French
entities.description: French refers to the nationality of people from France, a country in Western Europe.
The year in which the first modern Olympic Games were held in Athens, Greece.

entities.name: athletics
entities.description: Athletics, also known as track and field, includes various events such as running, jumping, throwing, and walking. It is one of the oldest and most popular sports in the world.

entities.name: swimming
entities.description: Swimming is one of the traditional events included in the Olympic Games, alongside athletics and other sports. It has been a part of the Games since their inception.

entities.name: snowboarding
entities.description: Snowboarding is a winter sport that involves descending snow-covered slopes while standing on a board attached to the rider"s feet.

entities.name: beach volleyball
entities.description: Beach volleyball is a team sport played by two teams of two players each on a sand court divided by a net.

entities.name: political disputes
entities.description: Political disputes refer to disagreements or conflicts over political issues, often involving different ideologies, policies, or interests.

attributes.Frequency: Throughout the history of the Olympic Games

entities.name: boycotts
entities.description: Boycotts are actions taken by individuals or groups to refuse participation in an event, often as a form of protest.

entities.name: doping scandals
entities.description: Doping scandals refer to incidents where athletes use prohibited substances or methods to enhance their performance, leading to disqualification and loss of medals.

entities.name: Nazi Germany
entities.description: Nazi Germany, officially known as the Third Reich, was a totalitarian state in Germany from 1933 to 1945 under the dictatorship of Adolf Hitler.

entities.name: Soviet Union
entities.description: The Soviet Union, officially known as the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR), was a federal socialist state that existed from 1922 to 1991.

entities.name: Afghanistan
entities.description: Afghanistan, officially the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan, is a landlocked country located in South-Central Asia. It has been involved in various conflicts and political disputes.

entities.name: athletes
entities.description: Athletes are individuals who compete in various sports events, including traditional and modern disciplines. They represent their city-states or countries and often use the platform to promote social causes.

attributes.Sports Participation: Running, Wrestling, Boxing, Chariot Racing, Athletics, Swimming, Snowboarding, Beach Volleyball

entities.name: medals
entities.description: Medals are awards given to athletes for their outstanding performances in the Olympic Games and other sporting events.

attributes.Context: Olympic Games and other sporting events

entities.name: Olympic motto
entities.description: The Olympic motto, "Citius, Altius, Fortius" (Faster, Higher, Stronger), embodies the spirit of the Games and inspires athletes to push themselves to new heights of achievement.

entities.name: Citius, Altius, Fortius
entities.description: The Olympic motto, "Citius, Altius, Fortius" (Faster, Higher, Stronger), embodies the spirit of the Games and inspires athletes to push themselves to new heights of achievement.

entities.name: sportsmanship
entities.description: Sportsmanship refers to the ethical and moral principles that govern fair play, respect for opponents, and adherence to rules in sports.

attributes.Importance: Essential for maintaining the spirit of competition and unity in sports events like the Olympic Games.

entities.name: respect
entities.description: Respect is an important value that emphasizes acknowledging the worth and dignity of all individuals, regardless of their background or status.

entities.name: Four Years
entities.description: A period of four years, also known as an Olympiad.

entities.name: Athletics, Swimming, Snowboarding, Beach Volleyball
entities.description: A variety of sports that have been included in the Olympic Games over time.

entities.name: Unity, Sportsmanship, Excellence
entities.description: Core values that the Olympic Games aim to promote.

entities.name: Various Cities Around the World
entities.description: Different cities have hosted the Olympic Games over the years.

entities.name: Political Issues, Doping Scandals
entities.description: Various controversies that have affected the Olympic Games.

entities.name: ancient Olympic Games
entities.description: The ancient Olympic Games were a series of athletic competitions held in honor of the Greek god Zeus. They began in 776 BC and continued for nearly 12 centuries until they were abolished by the Roman Emperor Theodosius in 393 AD.

entities.name: Olympia
entities.description: Olympia was an important city in ancient Greece, located in the western part of the Peloponnese peninsula. It is famous for being the site where the ancient Olympic Games were held.

entities.name: modern Olympic Games
entities.description: The modern Olympic Games are a major international multi-sport event held every four years. They were first held in Athens, Greece, in 1896.

entities.name: Ancient Olympic Games
entities.description: The ancient Olympics were a series of athletic competitions held in honor of Zeus, the king of the gods. They continued for nearly 12 centuries until they were abolished by the Roman Emperor Theodosius in 393 AD.

entities.name: Modern Olympic Games
entities.description: The Modern Olympic Games are a major international multi-sport event held every four years, featuring summer and winter sports.

entities.name: Olympia, Greece
entities.description: Olympia is an archaeological site and a modern town in Elis on the Peloponnese peninsula. It was the site of the ancient Olympic Games.

entities.name: First Modern Olympic Games
entities.description: The first modern Olympic Games were held in Athens, Greece, in 1896. Athletes from 14 countries participated in 43 events.

entities.name: Truce
entities.description: The truce, or "Ekecheiria," was a sacred armistice that allowed athletes and spectators to travel safely to the Olympic Games.

entities.name: Theodosius I
entities.description: Theodosius I was a Roman Emperor from 379 to 395 AD. He is known for being the last emperor to rule over both the Eastern and Western halves of the Roman Empire.

entities.name: Ancient Olympics
entities.description: The ancient Olympic Games were a series of athletic competitions held in Olympia, Greece, from the 8th century BC to the 4th century AD.

entities.name: Peace and Understanding Among Nations
entities.description: The values of peace and understanding among nations are fundamental to the Olympic spirit, emphasizing the role of sports in fostering international cooperation.

entities.name: Athens, Greece
entities.description: The capital and largest city of Greece.

entities.name: 14 Countries
entities.description: A group of 14 countries that sent athletes to the first modern Olympic Games.

entities.name: Ancient Greek City-States
entities.description: In ancient Greece, athletes from various city-states would gather to compete in a variety of events, including athletics.

entities.name: Modern Athletes
entities.description: Modern athletes use their platform to promote various causes and advocate for social change.

entities.name: Olympics
entities.description: The Olympic Games are a major international multi-sport event held every four years, featuring summer and winter sports.

entities.name: Sand Court
entities.description: A sand court is a flat, rectangular area covered with fine sand, suitable for playing beach volleyball.

entities.name: Boycotts
entities.description: Boycotts are actions where individuals or groups refuse to participate in an event, often as a form of protest.

entities.name: Doping Scandals
entities.description: Doping scandals involve athletes using performance-enhancing drugs, which is against the rules of the Olympic Games.

entities.name: 1980 Moscow Olympics
entities.description: The 1980 Summer Olympics, officially known as the Games of the XXII Olympiad, were held in Moscow, Soviet Union.

entities.name: Athletes
entities.description: Athletes are individuals who compete in various sports and physical activities.

entities.name: 1936 Berlin Olympics
entities.description: The 1936 Summer Olympics, officially known as the Games of the XI Olympiad, were held in Berlin, Germany.

entities.name: Western Countries
entities.description: A group of countries primarily located in North America and Western Europe that share democratic values and economic interests.

entities.name: City-States, Countries
entities.description: City-states and countries are geographical entities that athletes represent during competitions.

entities.name: Social Causes
entities.description: Social causes are issues or movements that athletes may support and advocate for.

entities.name: Doping Tests
entities.description: Doping tests are procedures used to ensure fair competition by detecting the use of performance-enhancing substances.

entities.name: Future Olympics
entities.description: Future editions of the Olympic Games will continue to be held, emphasizing the values that have made them significant.

entities.name: Athletes from All Corners of the Globe
entities.description: Athletes from diverse backgrounds, cultures, and nations come together to compete in various sports.

entities.name: Olympic Values
entities.description: The Olympic Values are a set of principles that guide the conduct and spirit of the Olympic Games, including respect, fair play, and sportsmanship.

entities.name: Unity
entities.description: Unity refers to a state where people from different backgrounds come together and work towards common goals.

entities.name: Sportsmanship
entities.description: Sportsmanship is the conduct of individuals in sports that reflects fairness, integrity, and respect for opponents.

entities.name: Fair Play
entities.description: Fair play is the concept of playing a game or sport according to the rules and in a fair manner.

entities.name: Global Participation
entities.description: Global participation refers to the involvement of people from all over the world in a common activity or event.
